facts.text: Plot of land admeasuring about 41 decimals situate within the municipal limits of Chandernagore.

Respondent No.1 is a society registered under the Societies Registration Act, XXXI of 1860. Its objects include to work, manage, develop, improve and utilise properties and business for the promotion of education, art, science, religion and charity or other useful objects.
On March 23, 1941, Kashinath Seal granted a permanent lease of the land in dispute to respondents 2 and 3.

By registered deed dated September 29, 1944, Kashinath Seal granted lease of the entire plot including disputed land to Motilal Roy for 99 years. Motilal Roy acquired only right of realising rent from disputed land leased to resp 2&3.
Motilal Roy was founder of 1st respondent and benamidar thereof.
By deed dated March 14, 1953, Motilal Roy relinquished all interest in the plot to 1st respondent.
By registered deed of sale with condition for reconveyance dated November 3, 1960, respondents 2 and 3 transferred disputed land to appellant and handed possession.
1st respondent applied under s24 WB Non-Agr Tenancy Act claiming right of transfer as immediate landlord, land contiguous to its lands, required for school extension.
Trial Court dismissed application: land not contiguous to 1st resp lands, but bona fide required for school expansion.

Appeal by 1st resp: Addl Dist Judge held land adjacent/contiguous, but 1st resp intermediary under WB Estates Acq Act s2(1)(i), interests vested in State post merger of Chandernagore, dismissed appeal.
1st resp filed revision in Calcutta HC under s116 CPC and Art 227 Const. HC repelled contentions, allowed revision, set aside dismissal.
Appeal by special leave to SC.

legal_issues.text: Whether 1st respondent is intermediary under s2(1)(i) WB Estates Acquisition Act 1954, interests vested in State.
Whether s24 WB Non-Agr Tenancy Act applies: land contiguous? Court satisfied required for purposes in s4 per proviso (b)?
Whether s24 applies to transfer by under-tenant to third party.
Constitutional validity of s24: unreasonable restriction on right to hold property under Art 19(1)(f).

petitioner_arguments.text: 1st resp intermediary under WB Estates Acq Act s2(1)(i), rights vested in State.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act, 1954 s2(1)(i)

petitioner_arguments.text: s24 does not apply as land not contiguous; proviso (b) requires court satisfaction for s4 purposes, no finding.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: WB Non-Agr Tenancy Act s24 proviso (b), s4

petitioner_arguments.text: s24 applies only to tenant transfer, not under-tenant to third party.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: WB Non-Agr Tenancy Act s24, s3

petitioner_arguments.text: s24 invalid as unreasonable restriction on Art 19(1)(f), based solely on vicinage.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Constitution Art 19(1)(f); Bhau Ram v. Baijnath Singh

respondent_arguments.text: Land contiguous to its lands, bona fide required for school expansion (business/education purposes under s4).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: WB Non-Agr Tenancy Act s24, s4(b),(c)

respondent_arguments.text: Not intermediary, as non-agri tenant itself.

court_reasoning.text: Land contiguous per Addl Dist Judge finding; HC finding of bona fide need for school expansion undisturbed; required for business/other purposes under s4(b),(c) as per society's objects.
s24 applies to under-tenants as s3 defines two classes of non-agri tenants: tenants and under-tenants; resp2&3 tenants of resp1.
Resp1 not intermediary under Estates Act s2(1)(i) as it is non-agri tenant itself.

s24 not solely on vicinage; part of scheme giving security of tenure, heritability, transferability to tenants/under-tenants; landlord right only on transfer to third party if contiguous and needed for s4 purposes; reasonable for public interest.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinguishes Bhau Ram (pure vicinage); cf Ram Sarup (valid with other factors).

holdings.text: Land contiguous and bona fide required for s4 purposes; s24 proviso (b) satisfied.
Under-tenants are 'non-agricultural tenants' under s3; s24 applies to their transfers.
Resp1 not intermediary; entitled to apply under s24.
s24 constitutionally valid; not unreasonable restriction under Art 19(1)(f).

precedents_cited.relevance: Struck down pre-emption solely on vicinage as unreasonable; but s24 has additional factors.
Pre-emption valid where beyond vicinage, for village integrity etc.

statutes_cited.name: West Bengal Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act, XX of 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines landlord, tenant, under-tenant; purposes of holding; transfer notice and right of landlord to purchase if contiguous and needed for s4 purposes; security of tenure.

statutes_cited.name: West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act, 1 of 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines intermediary; resp1 not intermediary as non-agri tenant.

statutes_cited.name: Societies Registration Act, XXXI of 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Resp1 registered society with educational objects.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Revision; right to property; no discrimination.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference to commencement for tenancy incidents.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court order upheld; 1st respondent entitled to transfer of land under s24 WB Non-Agr Tenancy Act.
outcome.relief_granted: Right of transfer to 1st respondent confirmed.

key_quotes.text: "there are two classes of non-agricultural tenants, namely, (a) tenants and (b) under-tenants and though sub-sections (2) and (3) define a tenant and an under-tenant both the categories are tenants for the purposes of the Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key to applying s24 to under-tenants.

key_quotes.text: "The scheme of the Act clearly is to afford security of tenure to tenants and under tenants even to the extent of making their rights transferable and heritable. It is only when such land is sought to be transferred that the immediate landlord is given the right to have it transferred to himself instead of to a third party."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains legislative object justifying s24 constitutionally.
